question: What two processes most commonly turn sediments into sedimentary rock?

content.source_1: In clastic sedimentary rocks, loose sediment derived from preexisting rocks is typically lithified by compaction under overburden and by cementation as minerals precipitate between grains.
content.source_2: By volume, the majority of sedimentary rocks in the geologic record are clastic (e.g., shale, sandstone, conglomerate) composed of fragments of older rocks.
content.source_3: Compaction and cementation are standard geological processes of lithification that convert deposited sediment into solid sedimentary rock.
content.source_4: Chemical sedimentary rocks such as rock salt and gypsum form when dissolved ions precipitate from evaporating water; this rock-forming pathway is evaporation and precipitation.
content.source_5: Over geologic time, extensive carbonate platforms and evaporite basins have built thick, laterally continuous successions of sedimentary rock produced primarily by mineral precipitation and recrystallization.
content.source_6: Many limestones (e.g., oolitic limestones) form by direct precipitation of calcium carbonate in warm, shallow seas, producing rock without prior compaction of transported clastic grains.
